html.en:
In this lesson, you'll learn how to:

  • recognise nasal mutation (NM) fast
  • use the core triggers: fy (my) and yn meaning in (with ym/yng)
  • avoid classic traps: no visible change, yn confusion, and one mutation only

 

Nasal mutation is not as constant as soft mutation, but it shows up in high-value places. If you can spot it quickly, reading and writing get a lot easier.

  • osgoi trapiau clasurol: dim newid gweladwy, dryswch yn, ac un treiglad yn unig

html.en:
For most learners, NM is mainly these:

  • fy (my) + noun
  • yn meaning in (spelled yn/ym/yng) + noun/place

 

You may hear less NM in casual speech. In writing, it matters more, and it is always worth recognising.

I‚Äôr rhan fwyaf o ddysgwyr, TT yw‚Äôr rhain yn bennaf:

  • fy + enw

Gallet ti glywed llai o TT ar lafar achlysurol. Mewn ysgrifennu, mae‚Äôn bwysicach, ac mae adnabod TT bob amser yn sgil dda.

NM only affects a small set of letters: c p t g b d.

 

If a word starts with something else, you may get no visible change even when the trigger is real.

 

  • fy siop i
  • yn Lloegr

 

Mindset: ‚Äúno change‚Äù can be correct Welsh. Your job is to spot the trigger and check whether the first letter is on the NM map.

In writing, it commonly appears as:

Think: choose yn/ym/yng, then apply NM if the next word starts with c p t g b d.

html.en:
This causes loads of confusion:

  • yn = in (preposition) can be yn/ym/yng and can trigger nasal.
  • yn as a linker after bod (often written 'n) is a grammar marker and very often involves soft mutation, not nasal.

 

MeaningExample
inDw i yng Nghymru
linker after bodDw i'n dda (da ‚Üí dda)

 

Quick check: if you can swap it for English in, it is the preposition and NM may be in play.
